Award.AwardTitle: Support for the Educational Activities at ACM CCS 2014

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The annual ACM CCS conference is a leading international forum for computer and communications security researchers, practitioners, developers, and users to explore cutting-edge ideas and results, and to exchange techniques, tools, and experiences. ACM CCS is the flagship event of ACM Special Interest Group of Security, Audit and Control (SIGSAC). Its acceptance rate is around 15-20%, which makes it a highly selective conference.

This grant provides support for 20 students to attend ACM CCS and associated workshops. Preference will be given to undergraduate students participating in the poster session, and students with papers in the conference or workshop who do not have other support. Participation by women and underrepresented groups will also be encouraged.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is to support the travel expenses of selected student attendees who presented their research work at ACM CCS which is the most prestigious research conference in the field of computer security. 

We have received 80+ applications from 9 different countries (USA, Australia, Sweden, Germany, Canada, South Korea, HongKong, United Kingdom, and Greece) and 13 applications were submitted by female students. One of top priorities was to fully support those female students. Among those 13 female applicants, the committee selected 8 female applicants and fully supported their travel expenses through another sponsorship that the PI secured for ACM CCS conference.

For this NSF travel award, the committee selected top 15 students from the rest of applications (75 applications) for ACM 2014. All of these 15 awardees were graduate students and they were from universities at USA (Florida, Georgia (2), Illinois (2), Indiana (2), Maryland, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Michigan, New York, North Carolina (2), Tennessee, and Texas). 

In addition, we supported 6 student attedees for ACM 2015. These awardees were from New York, North Dakota, Colorado (2), Arizona and Pennsylvania. 

With the NSF award, we were able to support the total of 21 students (including 4 female students) and PI additionally supported 13 female applicants through another sponsorship. 

Through this partial travel support, students were able to attend the conference and share their research agenda with leading security scientists. In addition, each student was able to attend each paper session and other events at ACM CCS so that they can learn the state-of- the-art technology and research challenges in the field of computer security.
